Apple scab.Description:
Apple scab is a fungal disease affecting apple leaves, blossoms, and fruits. 
Synonyms: Venturia leaf spot, Apple leaf blotch. 
Facts: Causes premature leaf drop; resistant apple varieties reduce incidence; early fungicide application is effective.
Apple scab.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Venturia inaequalis.
Apple scab.Symptoms: Dark, irregularly-shaped lesions on leaves, blossoms, and fruits; premature leaf and fruit drop may occur.
Apple scab.Prevention: Sanitize fallen leaves, ensure proper spacing and airflow, plant resistant varieties.
Apple scab.Treatment: Apply fungicides such as Captan or EBDCs at 2-week intervals during early growth.

Apple Black rot.Description:
Apple Black Rot is a fungal disease that causes dark lesions on apple fruits, leaves, and branches. 
Synonyms: Diplodia rot, Fruit rot. 
Facts: Affects storage quality of apples; pruning infected parts reduces spread.
Apple Black rot.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Diplodia seriata.
Apple Black rot.Symptoms: Dark lesions on leaves, branches, and fruits; fruit may shrivel and leaves may wilt.
Apple Black rot.Prevention: Remove infected plant parts, maintain orchard sanitation, plant resistant varieties.
Apple Black rot.Treatment: Use protectant fungicides like Mancozeb or Ziram before infection occurs.

Apple Cedar apple rust.Description:
Cedar apple rust is a fungal infection requiring both apple and cedar hosts. 
Synonyms: Gymnosporangium rust. 
Facts: Causes yellow-orange spots on leaves and fruits; can deform fruit.
Apple Cedar apple rust.Cause: Fungal infection requiring both apple and cedar hosts (Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae).
Apple Cedar apple rust.Symptoms: Yellow-orange spots on leaves and fruits; can cause fruit deformation.
Apple Cedar apple rust.Prevention: Remove nearby cedar trees, ensure proper airflow, plant resistant apple varieties.
Apple Cedar apple rust.Treatment: Fungicides containing Myclobutanil applied before infection spreads.

Apple healthy.Description:
Healthy apple plant. 
Synonyms: None. 
Facts: Green, healthy leaves and fruits; no lesions or discoloration; normal growth.
Apple healthy.Symptoms: Green, healthy leaves and fruits without lesions or discoloration.
Apple healthy.Prevention: Maintain proper watering, fertilization, and orchard sanitation.

Bacterial leaf blight in rice leaf.Description:
Bacterial leaf blight is caused by Xanthomonas oryzae. 
Synonyms: BLB. 
Facts: Yellowing of leaf tips progressing to brown lesions; reduces growth and yield.
Bacterial leaf blight in rice leaf.Cause: Bacterial infection caused by Xanthomonas oryzae.
Bacterial leaf blight in rice leaf.Symptoms: Yellowing of leaf tips progressing to brown lesions, leaf wilting, reduced growth.
Bacterial leaf blight in rice leaf.Prevention: Use resistant varieties, ensure proper field drainage, avoid excessive nitrogen.
Bacterial leaf blight in rice leaf.Treatment: Remove infected plants, apply copper-based bactericides if necessary.

Blight in corn Leaf.Description:
Corn leaf blight is a fungal infection caused by Setosphaeria turcica. 
Synonyms: Northern corn leaf blight. 
Facts: Elongated gray-green lesions on lower leaves; severe cases lead to leaf death.
Blight in corn Leaf.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Setosphaeria turcica.
Blight in corn Leaf.Symptoms: Elongated gray-green lesions on lower leaves, progressing upwards; leaf death in severe cases.
Blight in corn Leaf.Prevention: Plant resistant varieties, rotate crops, remove crop debris.
Blight in corn Leaf.Treatment: Apply fungicides at early symptom appearance to reduce spread.

Blueberry healthy.Description:
Healthy blueberry plant. 
Synonyms: None. 
Facts: Healthy leaves, stems, and berries; no spots or discoloration.
Blueberry healthy.Symptoms: Healthy leaves, stems, and berries; no spots or discoloration.
Blueberry healthy.Prevention: Provide balanced nutrition, avoid waterlogging, maintain good airflow.

Brown spot in rice leaf.Description:
Brown spot in rice leaf is a fungal infection caused by Cochliobolus miyabeanus. 
Synonyms: Helminthosporium leaf spot. 
Facts: Small brown circular lesions; may have yellow halos; affects yield.
Brown spot in rice leaf.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Cochliobolus miyabeanus.
Brown spot in rice leaf.Symptoms: Small brown circular lesions on leaves, sometimes surrounded by yellow halos.
Brown spot in rice leaf.Prevention: Use resistant varieties, avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, ensure good drainage.
Brown spot in rice leaf.Treatment: Seed treatment with tricyclazole; spray mancozeb or tricyclazole during tillering and booting stages.

Cercospora leaf spot.Description:
Cercospora leaf spot is caused by Cercospora spp. 
Synonyms: Grey leaf spot. 
Facts: Small dark spots may merge; leaves may yellow and drop.
Cercospora leaf spot.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Cercospora spp.
Cercospora leaf spot.Symptoms: Small dark spots on leaves, may merge into larger necrotic areas; leaves may yellow and drop.
Cercospora leaf spot.Prevention: Avoid overhead watering, ensure spacing for airflow, remove infected leaves.
Cercospora leaf spot.Treatment: Apply fungicides and maintain proper irrigation practices to reduce leaf wetness.

Cherry (including sour) Powdery mildew.Description:
Powdery mildew affects cherry plants, caused by Podosphaera clandestina. 
Synonyms: Mildew. 
Facts: White powdery growth on leaves, shoots, and fruits; stunts growth.
Cherry (including sour) Powdery mildew.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Podosphaera clandestina.
Cherry (including sour) Powdery mildew.Symptoms: White powdery growth on leaves, shoots, and fruits; may cause leaf curling and stunted growth.
Cherry (including sour) Powdery mildew.Prevention: Plant resistant cultivars, ensure proper pruning and airflow, avoid excessive nitrogen.
Cherry (including sour) Powdery mildew.Treatment: Use horticultural oils or fungicides designed for powdery mildew control.

Cherry healthy.Description:
Healthy cherry plant.

Facts: Healthy leaves, stems, and fruits; uniform color; no lesions.
Cherry healthy.Symptoms: Healthy leaves, stems, and fruits; uniform color and no lesions.
Cherry healthy.Prevention: Maintain proper irrigation, nutrition, and pruning.

Corn Common rust.Description:
Common rust of corn is a fungal disease caused by Puccinia sorghi. 
Synonyms: Corn rust. 
Facts: Small reddish-brown pustules on leaves; may reduce photosynthesis in severe cases.
Corn Common rust.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Puccinia sorghi.
Corn Common rust.Symptoms: Small reddish-brown pustules on leaves; may reduce photosynthesis in severe cases.
Corn Common rust.Prevention: Plant resistant varieties, remove volunteer corn plants, rotate crops.
Corn Common rust.Treatment: Fungicide application if infection is severe and conditions are favorable.

Gray leaf spot in corn is caused by Cercospora zeae-maydis. 
Synonyms: GLS. 
Facts: Rectangular gray lesions along veins; severe infections reduce yield.
Corn Gray leaf spot.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Cercospora zeae-maydis.
Corn Gray leaf spot.Symptoms: Rectangular gray lesions along leaf veins; leaves may wither in severe infections.
Corn Gray leaf spot.Prevention: Rotate crops, use resistant hybrids, remove crop residue.
Corn Gray leaf spot.Treatment: Apply fungicides at early lesion development to prevent spread.

Grape Black rot.Description:
Grape Black Rot is a fungal disease caused by Guignardia bidwellii. 
Synonyms: Black rot of grape. 
Facts: Dark lesions on leaves and fruits; infected berries shrivel.
Grape Black rot.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Guignardia bidwellii.
Grape Black rot.Symptoms: Dark, circular lesions on leaves and fruits; infected berries shrivel.
Grape Black rot.Prevention: Prune for airflow, remove mummified berries, plant resistant varieties.
Grape Black rot.Treatment: Apply fungicides such as Captan during susceptible growth stages.

Esca or Black Measles affects grapevines.

Facts: Dark streaks in wood, black spots on berries, vine decline over years.
Grape Esca Black Measles.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Phaeomoniella chlamydospora and Phaeoacremonium spp.
Grape Esca Black Measles.Symptoms: Dark streaks in wood, black spots on berries, leaf yellowing, vine decline over years.
Grape Esca Black Measles.Prevention: Use healthy planting material, avoid pruning wounds, remove infected wood.
Grape Esca Black Measles.Treatment: No chemical cure; remove affected parts and manage vineyard sanitation.

Healthy grapevine.

Orange Citrus canker.Cause: Bacterial infection caused by Xanthomonas citri.
Orange Citrus canker.Symptoms: Raised lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits; leaves may drop prematurely.
Orange Citrus canker.Prevention: Use disease-free plants, prune carefully, avoid overhead irrigation.
Orange Citrus canker.Treatment: Copper-based bactericides; remove infected plant parts.

Healthy orange plant.

Anthracnose in tea.Description:
Anthracnose in tea is a fungal disease caused by Colletotrichum species. It affects leaves and young shoots, particularly in humid conditions. 
Facts: Causes leaf spots, shoot dieback, and can reduce yield.
Anthracnose in tea.Cause: Fungal infection caused by Colletotrichum species, commonly Colletotrichum camelliae.
Anthracnose in tea.Symptoms: Small brown to dark-brown circular or irregular spots on young leaves; severe infections cause leaf curling, drying, and falling; shoot dieback and stem lesions may occur.
Anthracnose in tea.Prevention: Prune and remove infected leaves and shoots; maintain proper spacing for airflow; collect and destroy fallen infected leaves; use resistant cultivars if available.
Anthracnose in tea.Treatment: Apply copper-based fungicides or systemic fungicides like Carbendazim and Mancozeb as recommended; ensure proper drainage and reduce leaf wetness.

Algal leaf in tea.Prevention: Ensure good drainage, avoid overhead watering, maintain proper spacing for airflow.
Algal leaf in tea.Treatment: Apply copper-based fungicides; remove and destroy infected leaves.

Bird eye spot in tea.Symptoms: Small circular spots with dark centers and lighter halos on leaves.
Bird eye spot in tea.Prevention: Prune infected leaves, improve ventilation, avoid excessive humidity.
Bird eye spot in tea.Treatment: Fungicide sprays such as copper oxychloride or mancozeb.

Brown blight in tea.Prevention: Sanitation practices, use resistant varieties, proper pruning.
Brown blight in tea.Treatment: Apply fungicides like carbendazim or copper-based products.

Potato hollow heart.Treatment: Not applicable; manage through cultural practices.
